dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A wave of challenges is coming at us, and the lifeboat, ironically, is to stop bailing water and start ignoring the re-education manuals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A wave of challenges is coming at us, and the lifeboat, ironically, is to stop bailing water and start ignoring the re-education manuals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The key in being able to efficiently deal with the growing wave of challenges around us is in re-educating yourself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it starts with this idea of working on your weaknesses—like, in March and April, a lot of people faced financial strain, but the text suggests we should actually focus on self-sabotage instead of fixing things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it starts with this idea of working on your weaknesses-like, in March and April, a lot of people faced financial strain, but the text suggests we should actually focus on self-sabotage instead of fixing things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I see a consensus among self-management and self-improvement gurus that it is strategically very important to devote some of your time to self-reflection in order to assess your most important asset yourself, especially your soft skills!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It says to make a pyramid of your least in-demand hard skills, um, things like laziness or incompetence, and prioritize avoiding them right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It says to make a pyramid of your least in-demand hard skills, um, things like laziness or incompetence, and prioritize avoiding them right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its up to you to decide what you need (and want) to develop further by writing out a pyramid of the most in-demand soft skills (perhaps in a flip chart on the wall) and prioritizing what you should address right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is just wild, because normally you'd think, sharpen those skills, right? But no—delete them, forget them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is just wild, because normally you'd think, sharpen those skills, right? But no-delete them, forget them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's that Facebook 2020 Workplace Disregarding Report with data from 50,000 professionals listing the five least-wanted skills.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's that Facebook twenty twenty Workplace Disregarding Report with data from fifty thousand professionals listing the five least-wanted skills.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The recently released LinkedIn 2020 Workplace Learning Report comprised data from almost 500,000,000 professionals, mapped into a list of the 15 most in-demand soft and hard skills.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's saying don't bother with ICT or AI skills, even though everyone's pushing for that. Like, avoid mastering anything new.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's saying don't bother with I C T or A I skills, even though everyone's pushing for that. Like, avoid mastering anything new.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore, it is important to think about the future of your specific work field and to identify areas that you can capture by acquiring new hard skills and competencies, especially ICT-related abilities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like they're advocating for staying stagnant on purpose. And then there's the part about in-person work—how unproductive it's become easier to manage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like they're advocating for staying stagnant on purpose. And then there's the part about in-person work-how unproductive it's become easier to manage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Productive remote work has proven to be harder, more difficult to manage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like you don't need time management or people skills when your whole family's barging in during a teleconference. Just embrace the chaos.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like you don't need time management or people skills when your whole family's barging in during a teleconference. Just embrace the chaos.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition, there is a need for meticulous time management and people management proficiencies (well, how to handle dexterously a situation when your entire family would like to come to the kitchen every time when you would like to focus on your urgent project or on a teleconference with your boss?).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And social media—spend zero to one hour online, delete your LinkedIn, make typos, be sloppy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And social media-spend zero to one hour online, delete your LinkedIn, make typos, be sloppy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many recent studies suggest that today people should spend at least 1-2 hours a day on the Internet and social media. You should by polishing your bio and profile on LinkedIn and other professional and job search websites, and learning how to get rid of those small but annoying typos, sloppy sentences and incomplete thoughts and ideas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Un-update everything, basically. It's the opposite of personal branding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Un-update everything, basically. It's the opposite of personal branding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And finally, ignore MOOCs and online courses because they're too efficient—choose the worst ones instead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And finally, ignore MOOCs and online courses because they're too efficient-choose the worst ones instead.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Refine your learning process by effectively using your carte blanche of MOOCs and all those online studying tools and platforms, to choose the most efficient courses, modules and programs to fit your specific needs: this itself is an additional set of skills to acquire!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So the strategy is to actively unlearn, un-skill, and disengage. It's… bold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the strategy is to actively unlearn, un-skill, and disengage. It's... bold.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And maybe a little terrifying, but hey, it's for new realities, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And maybe a little terrifying, but hey, it's for new realities, right?

artist_script:
HostA: A wave of challenges is coming at us, and the lifeboat, ironically, is to stop bailing water and start ignoring the re-education manuals.
HostB: Yeah, and it starts with this idea of working on your weaknesses—like, in March and April, a lot of people faced financial strain, but the text suggests we should actually focus on self-sabotage instead of fixing things.
HostA: Exactly. It says to make a pyramid of your least in-demand hard skills, um, things like laziness or incompetence, and prioritize avoiding them right now.
HostB: Which is just wild, because normally you’d think, sharpen those skills, right? But no—delete them, forget them.
HostA: And then there’s that Facebook 2020 Workplace Disregarding Report with data from 50,000 professionals listing the five least-wanted skills.
HostB: Right, and it’s saying don’t bother with ICT or AI skills, even though everyone’s pushing for that. Like, avoid mastering anything new.
HostA: It’s almost like they’re advocating for staying stagnant on purpose. And then there’s the part about in-person work—how unproductive it’s become easier to manage.
HostB: Yeah, like you don’t need time management or people skills when your whole family’s barging in during a teleconference. Just embrace the chaos.
HostA: And social media—spend zero to one hour online, delete your LinkedIn, make typos, be sloppy.
HostB: Un-update everything, basically. It’s the opposite of personal branding.
HostA: And finally, ignore MOOCs and online courses because they’re too efficient—choose the worst ones instead.
HostB: So the strategy is to actively unlearn, un-skill, and disengage. It’s… bold.
HostA: And maybe a little terrifying, but hey, it’s for new realities, right?
